raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "GI upset", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "The clinical scenario describes a child with absence seizures (brief 'spacing out', normal development, 3-Hz spike and wave on EEG). The first-line treatment is ethosuximide, whose most common side effect is GI upset (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain). The other options are associated with other antiepileptics: nystagmus (phenytoin), facial rash and blood in urine (lamotrigine or phenytoin, but not ethosuximide), and weight gain/change in hair color (not typical for ethosuximide)."}
